snippet: Comparisons of the real value of today’s minimum wage with what prevailed decades ago fail to account for the rise of the earned-income tax credit as a primary vehicle for helping low-income families, an economist writes.
abstract: Comparisons of the real value of today’s minimum wage with what prevailed decades ago fail to account for the rise of the earned-income tax credit as a primary vehicle for helping low-income families, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: David Neumark is professor of economics and director of the Center for Economics and Public Policy at the University of California, Irvine.

headline.main: The Minimum Wage Ain’t What It Used to Be
